text: The accident was a
big change in my life, as you can imagine.
We were in Costa Rica with my husband

and our two young kids were staying
with my parents in Casablanca.
We went cycling to the beach
and I fell off a bridge.

You cannot imagine that something
like this can happen
just in a few seconds.
And when my husband came to

help me, he thought I would, 
you know, get up.
And I told him I'm paralyzed.
He said, no, it's not possible.

Then I had to be rescued because
it was in the middle of nowhere

and it took 8 hours to go
to the hospital in San Jose.
It was really hard for my husband
because he was alone.

Fortunately, we had some friends there
so they could help us
by coming and searching for us by plane.
How was it when you returned to Morocco?

At the beginning, it was 
really difficult because I

realized that there was nothing done
for people with disabilities in Morocco.
We wouldn't even see them in the street.

So the first times were
very difficult.

You know, the first time
you go to the restaurant.

The first time you go to the pool,
to the movies,
to the car, to travel.
All the first times are really difficult.

It was complicated because
there was absolutely no accessibility.

Fortunately, my husband is very
strong and my friends could help.
But I'm a woman. I'm light.
I smile. So for me, it's easy.

But for the people who are
maybe heavier or don't smile -

they stay stuck in their wheelchair
and that's it, when they have a wheelchair.

So it was really astonishing
to see this lack of

dedicated facilities for
disabled people in Morocco.
I had a choice, you know -
should I fight or should I surrender?
I decided to use my wheelchair like a tool

to ignite some change,
you know, in the mindset

of not only the public,
but also the government.

It was really powerful,
really powerful because I was here,

having my place and saying,
okay, I'm here,
and you have to listen to us

because there are a lot of
things to do and to change.
